pages.text: Brembodus ridens is a species of Pycnodont bony fish from the late Triassic of Italy. This fish had a round and flattened body, not dissimilar to modern day reef fishes, and possessed a characteristic elongated spike on the top of its body originating right behind the head.

The small jaws were remarkably strong with a specialised dentition made to chew hard foods. The frontal teeth looked remarkably similar to incisors in mammals while the many back rows were oval and flattened.

Brembodus was one of the first pycnodonts, a group of durophagous animals characteristic of most of the Mesozoic and the beginning of the Cenozoic. Brembodus lived around cliff sides and rocks, slowly swimming while foraging for food.
